This was the first time I attended Ferragosto in the Bronx little Italy. In September of 2024.
It was an amazing experience of music,  the smells of good food, and a wonderful atmosphere.
I had lunch at Enzo's, and the fried meatballs appetizer was amazing with a great flavor.  I also brought some of Enzo's sauce and macaroni home.
I will definitely be back next year.
If you ever get the chance to go,  definitely go and enjoy the wonderful atmosphere.

This is a great Little Italy.

Very authentic.  Great bakeries, restaurants and coffee.  Enzo's is great for pasta, probably the best anywhere.

Great place to explore.

This Little Italy lacks the aesthetics of Mulberry Street.  But, it seems more authentic and less touristy.

In movie land language, this is Tessio's territory.  It was later run by Sonny, as related by Calogero, who was known as "C".

A place with a now diverse culture and great restaurants everywhere you look. Not to mention the chance to see a list actors that come either because they lived here or for little Italy's famous once mafia spots restaurants Chaz palmentierri is one that comes often.
Love Little Italy Bronx.  Great restaurants and stores
What a great section of town. In the morning we had a bagel. In the afternoon I had an unbelievable sandwich at one of the local shops.
Superb!!!
Felt like being back in Italy. Was able to find all the Italian products we cant find in upstate NY. Friendly people and will be making a shopping trip down to pick some great food!

You will find italian stores, coffee! Lots of coffee! Restaurants, fresh pizza and more coffee!
Just a bit complicated to get there, the bus stops away.

Interesting neighbourhood. You really don‚Äôt feel that you are in Bronx! Like an oasis in desert. Many nice restaurants and pubs. You can buy fresh pasta in Italian grocery store.

Start at prince coffee house on Arthur Avenue with a fantastic coffee and great people watching.  We heard Italian at every table.  Then go up Arthur Avenue to the indoor Arthur Avenue retail market which is amazing.  Everything from cigars‚Ä¶

CALLING ALL PIZZA LOVERS!! Visited during the 1st annual pizza festival this year! Let's just say u missed a one of a kind experience that only happens once a year and it started this year(2018). Add it to ur list of things to do for 2019!‚Ä¶
Il primo locale italiano che abbiamo incontrato in cui ci lavorava un‚Äôitaliano. Servizio e accoglienza discreti.
Muy bonito. Todo bien limplio. Siempre hay parqueo, buenos restaurantes de rica comida Italiana.
Un panorama espectacular para realizar en familia lo mejor del Bronx.
Alot better than manhatten little  Italy. A more homey, local feel. Dont forget to go see the salami chandelier at the Calabria Pork Store and get some homemade salami to go!

Interessante e fuori dai normali itinerari turistici trattandosi del Bronx.
Nn molto agevole da raggiungere con subway da manathan...prendere la linea D

Being Italian, I really love this area. There are some great spots to get pastries. The restaurants here are also great; tons of different variation. As far as comparing it to the Little Italy in Manhattan, it does not seem nearly as touristy. There are not a bunch of cheap souvenir shops around every corner, so that is nice.

I grew up a few blocks from here, went to MS 45. The food here is phenomenal. Nothing on Cross Bay Blvd (Howard Beach) compares to this! Coffee, lunch, dinner, dessert, freshly baked bread, fresh handmade noodles, you cannot go wrong at any of these shops here.
I love it... had so much fun with my Fiance, we went to the market and a Fancy restaurant.

Brought my 94 year old mother in law here. She hasn't been here in 40 years. Loved all the bakeries. We had the time of our lives. Now that she's passed on this place and that day will always be special to me. To all the store owners thx for a fond memory

Now - while it is a bit quiet - take an afternoon to just wander this little neighborhood of Italian delights.  No rush. No pressure.  Just walk up and down, stick your head in. Grab a coffee or a slice (or  more!) and go to one of the‚Ä¶

I had so much fun finding interesting foods and enjoying the neighborhood plan to go back. I visited a number of stores. The best thing to do before going is decide ahead of time which shops interest you the most and go to to them first. Information of the area can be found online.

So much culture! Old school Italian bakeries. If you drive by at 4 or 5 in the morning you can smell the fresh Italian bread as your are driving by. The neighborhood has changed but a lot of the old business and pizza shops are still around!

Great place to go when they have the feast every year in the summer time!

Having live 10 years in Italy and arriving in New York to live and looking for some good Italian products I have been to both the Mulberry Street Little Italy and the Bronx Little Italy. Both are good for different reasons. I like the cafes where you can sit outside in the Bronx Little Italy. A few of the shops are nice and you can get some nice Italian products. But the pizza in Bronx Little Italy is horrible. The Italian bakery has a fantastic Neapolitan Baba but the service is not very friendly. There are some good Italian restaurants and the best part of Bronx Little Italy is the indoor marketplace. It feels like an outdoor Marketplace in Italy. The butcher there has fantastic homemade sausage and other great meets. You can find lots of nice Italian products decent produce and fresh bread. Still I prefer the traditional Little Italy on Mulberry Street even though it is shrinking more every year as the Chinese take over the area and the Young Generation of Italians move away to New Jersey. Bronx Little Italy is worth a visit but I would avoid the pizza

One of the great Bronx ethnic neighborhoods! Filled with Italian pastry shops, cafes, restaurants and pizza. The Italian food market has a variety of great Italian food products and raviolis. Other great restaurants from the Latino and Albanian community are in the area too.

I lived around Arthur Avenue for three years when I was in NY. It was my first home in the States. A historical neighborhood (over 112 years!) that has a lot of culture - as well as a great diversity of culture. Many of my neighbors had spent most of their life here --- though not in my building. Stop by one of the restaurants or barbershops or cheese shops or bars and you will discover layers of histories --- how people came to settle down here from different continents years ago. A few steps to the New York Botanical Garden (, my favorite spot for a walk, about 15 minutes by walking, ) the Bronx Zoo, and to the subway stations. They celebrated San Antonio Day and Little Italy Day annually, with a lot of music and bright colors. Plus there were some mom-and-pop Italian restaurants that offered classic, richly flavored heroes, pizzas, pastries, and desserts. Life was hard in New York but it was absolutely memorable.

Very cool. Tough to get to from the city. Would not recommend walking from Tremont Station like we did. Uber or so at another station. Cool shops. Interesting people. Some really good food and some very average food, too. Hunt for the good food

It's not really little Italy, it's more like little Mexico now.   Disappointed by everything here. The pastries they have you can get anywhere. Nothing like Italy actually. Maybe to Italian Americans, but I wasn't impressed. I did go on Sunday though so maybe I missed all the good stuff, won't find out because I'm not returning.

The ever so famous Little Italy, right here in the Boogie Down Bronx. So many eateries, high class mind you. So many local shops selling goods you rarely find anywhere else such as bakeries, wine shops, specialty food markets, etc. I‚Ä¶

Best little Italy left in NY. Can still find  great Italian products, restaurants, bakeries, markets, butchers and fresh seafood. Love eating raw oysters and clams right out front the shop! Many shops are not open on Sundays. Mix of some‚Ä¶
